articles.description: Using an artificial intelligence approach capable of decoding brain activity during sleep, scientists were able to glimpse what we think about when we are asleep. By combining fMRI and EEG, they provide unprecedented evidence that the work of sorting out the thousands of pieces of information processed during the day takes place during deep sleep. Indeed, the brain can evaluate all of these memories in order to retain only the most useful ones.
articles.title: What does the sleeping brain think about?

articles.description: Researchers have found that exposure to specific types of light before sleep can have variable effects on energy metabolism during sleep. Specifically, participants who went to sleep after exposure to organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), which emit polychromatic white light that contains less blue light than light-emitting diodes (LEDs), exhibited significantly decreased energy expenditure, core body temperature, and increased fat oxidation, indicating fewer negative health consequences compared with after nighttime exposure to LEDs.
articles.title: Exposure to light with less blue before sleep is better for energy metabolism

articles.description: Light therapy can help improve the mood of people with seasonal affective disorder (SAD) during short winter days, but exactly how this therapy works is not well understood. A new study finds that light therapy's beneficial effects come from activating the circadian clock gene Period1 in a part of the brain involved in mood and sleep-wake cycles.
articles.title: Scientists show how light therapy treats depression in mice model

articles.description: A new study looked at the consequences of sleeping fewer than six hours for eight consecutive nights -- the minimum duration of sleep that experts say is necessary to support optimal health in average adults.
articles.title: New study uncovers how a series of sleep loss impacts mental and physical wellbeing

articles.description: Physical activity levels at or above the weekly recommended amounts may counter the serious health harms associated with poor sleep quality, suggests a large long term study.
articles.title: High physical activity levels may counter serious health harms of poor sleep

articles.description: Researchers have created a mouse model that allows the study of naturally occurring melatonin. Experiments using the new mice showed that natural melatonin was linked to a pre-hibernation state that allows mice to slow down their metabolism and survive when food is scarce.
articles.title: Melatonin in mice: there's more to this hormone than sleep

articles.description: A research team found that FMAR was associated with preclinical AD pathology in women, suggesting that FMAR may be a new biomarker for AD before cognitive symptoms begin.
articles.title: Subconscious changes in movement may predict Alzheimer's disease

articles.description: The link between the different hierarchies of personality, sleep patterns and even genetics has now been discovered.
articles.title: Personality traits relate to being a morning or evening person

articles.description: A new position statement emphasizes that sleep is a biological necessity, and insufficient sleep and untreated sleep disorders are detrimental for health, well-being, and public safety.
articles.title: New position statement declares that sleep is essential to health

articles.description: An interdisciplinary team has determined that older adult women converse more effectively with strangers than their younger counterparts; additionally, communicating with female friends decreases stress hormone levels for women across the lifespan.
articles.title: Keep your friends close, cortisol levels low for life

articles.description: Researchers can gather highly accurate information about social trends and groups by asking about a person's social circle rather than interrogating their own individual beliefs.
articles.title: Researchers look to human 'social sensors' to better predict elections and other trends

articles.description: Want to have a happy relationship? Make sure both partners feel they can decide on issues that are important to them. Objective power measured by income, for example, doesn't seem to play a big role, according to a new study. Instead, how lovers perceive power dynamics in their relationship is most important for relationship satisfaction.
articles.title: Love: How the feeling of power determines happy relationships

articles.description: Summer holiday school catch-up programs to address gaps in knowledge after school closures need to support children who are still struggling due to social isolation.
articles.title: Summer catch-up programs need to focus on teens' wellbeing, not just academic progress

articles.description: Anti-androgen therapy is commonly used to treat patients with advanced prostate cancer at stages where the disease has spread to the bones. However, new research has found that anti-androgen treatment can actually facilitate prostate cancer cells to adapt and grow in the bone tumor microenvironment model developed by biomedical scientists.
articles.title: Anti-androgen therapy can fuel spread of bone tumors in advanced prostate cancer

articles.description: A small regulatory RNA found in many problematic bacteria, including Escherichia coli, appears to be responsible for managing the response of these bacteria to environmental stresses. Researchers see a promising avenue for more effective treatment of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
articles.title: A new avenue for fighting drug-resistant bacteria

articles.description: Keeping your brain active in old age has always been a smart idea, but a new study suggests that reading, writing letters and playing card games or puzzles in later life may delay the onset of Alzheimer's dementia by up to five years.
articles.title: Think about this: Keeping your brain active may delay Alzheimer's dementia 5 years

articles.description: The main driver of Alzheimer's disease is excessive inflammation in the brain that is triggered by cells called astrocytes and microglia in response to high levels of amyloid beta deposits and tau tangles. New research reveals that a subset of astrocytes releases a molecule called interleukin-3 that instructs microglia to adopt a protective response and clear away amyloid beta deposits and tau tangles. Interleukin-3 may hold promise as a new therapeutic intervention in Alzheimer's disease.
articles.title: Signaling molecule may help prevent Alzheimer's disease

articles.description: A recently published study identifies 11 rare candidate variants for Alzheimer's disease. Researchers found 19 different families in Utah that suffered from Alzheimer's disease more frequently than what is considered normal.
articles.title: Recent study identifies 11 candidate genetic variants for Alzheimer's disease

articles.description: Researchers have created an inflammatory clock of aging (iAge) which measures inflammatory load and predicts multi-morbidity, frailty, immune health, cardiovascular aging and is also associated with exceptional longevity in centenarians.
articles.title: 'Clock' created to predict immunological health and chronic diseases of aging

articles.description: A new study sheds light on how the specter of dementia and chronic pain reduce people's desire to live into older ages. Among Norwegians 60 years of age and older the desire to live into advanced ages was significantly reduced by hypothetical adverse life scenarios with the strongest effect caused by dementia and chronic pain.
articles.title: Preferred life expectancy and its association with hypothetical adverse life scenarios

articles.description: When it comes to post-menopausal hormone therapy, the type, route and duration all play a role in reducing the risk of neurodegenerative diseases.
articles.title: A step toward advancing precision hormone therapies to reduce Alzheimer's risk

articles.description: Researchers have found that nuclear factor E2-related factor 2, a master regulator of the oxidative stress response, affects muscle composition in microgravity. Targeting this protein could help protect against muscle changes during space flight, and could also have implications for muscle wasting in conditions such as cancer and aging.
articles.title: An antioxidative stress regulator protects muscle tissue in space, mouse study shows

articles.description: The vast majority of electronic health record (EHR) alerts attempting to reduce prescribing of high-risk medications linked to dementia in older adults went unread in a new study.
articles.title: EHR alerts go unread, do not lead to deprescribing of medicines linked to dementia

articles.description: Tooth loss is a risk factor for cognitive impairment and dementia -- and with each tooth lost, the risk of cognitive decline grows, according to a new analysis.
articles.title: Tooth loss associated with increased cognitive impairment, dementia

articles.description: A new study calculates the probability of living past age 110, which, though rare, likely will increase this century.
articles.title: How long can a person live? The 21st century may see a record-breaker

articles.description: Researchers have identified a new treatment candidate that appears to not only halt neurodegenerative symptoms in mouse models of dementia and Alzheimer's disease, but also reverse the effects of the disorders.
articles.title: Success in reversing dementia in mice sets the stage for human clinical trials

articles.description: Experts estimate more than 6 million Americans are living with Alzheimer's dementia. But a recent study sheds new light on the disease and a highly debated new drug therapy.
articles.title: Researchers question prevailing Alzheimer's theory with new discovery

articles.description: GluN3A-deficient mice display all aspects of Alzheimer's neurodegeneration.
articles.title: GluN3A knockout mouse: Alternative model for Alzheimer's neurodegeneration

articles.description: An international research team has developed a simple but robust blood test from Chinese patient data for early detection and screening of Alzheimer's disease (AD) with an accuracy level of over 96%.
articles.title: Scientists develop simple blood test for early detection of Alzheimer's disease

articles.description: People with dementia receiving home health care visits are less likely to be readmitted to the hospital when there is consistency in nursing staff, according to a new study.
articles.title: Having the same nurse for home health visits may prevent rehospitalization for people with dementia

articles.description: A growing trove of data to help scientists understand the biology of Alzheimer's disease among diverse populations within the context of sociocultural, behavioral and environmental factors is now available.
articles.title: Early findings of Alzheimer's study in diverse populations now available to researchers

articles.description: Researchers fed fruit flies antibiotics and monitored the lifetime activity of hundreds of genes that scientists have traditionally thought control aging. To their surprise, the antibiotics not only extended the lives of the flies but also dramatically changed the activity of many of these genes. Their results suggested that only about 30% of the genes traditionally associated with aging set an animal's internal clock while the rest reflect the body's response to bacteria.
articles.title: Scientists may need to rethink which genes control aging, study suggests

articles.description: Ultrasound can overcome some of the detrimental effects of ageing and dementia without the need to cross the blood-brain barrier, researchers have found.
articles.title: Non-invasive potential treatment for Alzheimer's disease

articles.description: Researchers have found that high levels of a normal protein associated with reduced heart disease also protect against Alzheimer's-like damage in mice, opening up new approaches to slowing or stopping brain damage and cognitive decline in people with Alzheimer's.
articles.title: Protein linked to heart health, disease a potential therapeutic target for dementia

articles.description: In a new study researchers report that elevated levels of two chemical mediators of inflammation, known as cytokines, are associated with slower cognitive decline in aging adults.
articles.title: An unexpected discovery: Inflammatory proteins may slow cognitive decline in aging adults

articles.description: With the National Eye Institute reporting that about 11 million older adults in the U.S. endure a condition that leads to progressive blindness, known as age-related macular degeneration, researchers are starting to understand what goes wrong in the disease, in order to develop new therapies to treat it.
articles.title: Recycling of the eye's light sensors is faulty in progressive blindness of older adults

articles.description: A research team found that FMAR was associated with preclinical AD pathology in women, suggesting that FMAR may be a new biomarker for AD before cognitive symptoms begin.
articles.title: Subconscious changes in movement may predict Alzheimer's disease

articles.description: A new study offers quantitative evidence linking psychological stress to graying hair in people.
articles.title: It's true: Stress does turn hair gray (and it's reversible)

articles.description: A new study suggests that unrepaired DNA damage can increase the speed of aging.
articles.title: Exposure to pollutants, increased free-radical damage speeds up aging

articles.description: A blood test that can detect tiny amounts of circulating cancer DNA may be able to identify risk of cancer recurrence and guide precision treatment in bladder cancer following surgery, according to a clinical study.
articles.title: Study suggests blood test could guide precision treatment in bladder cancer

articles.description: The mitochondrion has garnered quite the reputation for its role as the 'powerhouse of the cell.' These tiny, but mighty organelles play various life-sustaining roles, from powering our own cells and organs to fueling chemical and biological processes. But when they aren't working properly, a number of rare diseases can occur.
articles.title: Researcher creates cell lines to help treat mitochondrial diseases in children

articles.description: A higher intake of ultra-processed food is associated with higher risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), finds a new study.
articles.title: Ultra-processed food linked to higher risk of IBD

articles.description: A study finds middle- to older-aged adults who ate more servings of whole grains, compared to those who ate fewer, were more likely to have smaller increases in waist size, blood pressure, and blood sugar levels as they aged. All three are linked with increased risk of heart disease.
articles.title: Eating whole grains linked to smaller increases in waist size, blood pressure, blood sugar

articles.description: A new study shows that a diet rich in isoflavone, a phytoestrogen or plant-based compound that resembles estrogen, protects against multiple sclerosis-like symptoms in a mouse model of the disease. Importantly, the isoflavone diet was only protective when the mice had gut microbes capable of breaking down the isoflavones.
articles.title: Combining plant-based diet and healthy microbiome may protect against multiple sclerosis

articles.description: A diet rich in fermented foods enhances the diversity of gut microbes and decreases molecular signs of inflammation, according to researchers.
articles.title: A fermented-food diet increases microbiome diversity and lowers inflammation, study finds

articles.description: A modified ketogenic diet may be worth exploring for people with brain tumors, according to a new study. The small study found that the diet was safe and feasible for people with brain tumors called astrocytomas. The study was not designed to determine whether the diet could slow down tumor growth or improve survival.
articles.title: Could ketogenic diet be helpful with brain cancer?

articles.description: You dash into a convenience store for a quick snack, spot an apple and reach for a candy bar instead. Poor self-control may not be the only factor behind your choice, new research suggests. That's because our brains process taste information first, before factoring in health information, according to new research.
articles.title: When taste and healthfulness compete, taste has a hidden advantage

articles.description: The research sought to uncover the relationship between temperament and eating behaviors in early childhood. The findings are critical because faster eating and greater responsiveness to food cues have been linked to obesity risk in children.
articles.title: Impulsiveness tied to faster eating in children, can lead to obesity

articles.description: A research team's deeper examination of the nutritional content of plant-based meat alternatives, using metabolomics, shows they're as different as plants and animals. Beef contained 22 metabolites that the plant substitute did not. The plant-based substitute contained 31 metabolites that meat did not. The greatest distinctions occurred in amino acids, dipeptides, vitamins, phenols, and types of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids found in these products.
articles.title: Lab analysis finds near-meat and meat not nutritionally equivalent

articles.description: Flies have discriminating taste. Like a gourmet perusing a menu, they spend much of their time seeking sweet nutritious calories and avoiding bitter, potentially toxic food. But what happens in their brains when they make these food choices? Researchers discovered an interesting way to find out. They tricked them.
articles.title: More filling? Tastes great? How flies, and maybe people, choose their food

articles.description: Contrary to what science once suggested, older people with a declining sense of smell do not have comprehensively dampened olfactory ability for odors in general -- it simply depends upon the type of odor. Researchers reached this conclusion after examining a large group of older Danes' and their intensity perception of common food odors.
articles.title: The sense of smell in older adults declines when it comes to meat, but not vanilla, researchers find

articles.description: A diet higher in fatty fish helped frequent migraine sufferers reduce their monthly number of headaches and intensity of pain compared to participants on a diet higher in vegetable-based fats and oils, according to a new study.
articles.title: Consuming a diet with more fish fats, less vegetable oils can reduce migraine headaches, study finds

articles.description: A new study found that eating disorder behaviors alter the brain's reward response process and food intake control circuitry, which can reinforce the behaviors.
articles.title: Eating disorder behaviors alter reward response in brain

articles.description: Participants in a large-scale study who more commonly consumed a Southern-style diet - high in added fats, fried foods, processed meats and sugary drinks - had a higher risk of sudden cardiac death than people who had lower adherence to a Southern-style diet.
articles.title: The Southern diet - fried foods and sugary drinks - may raise risk of sudden cardiac death

articles.description: Researchers believe the liver may hold the key to new, preventative Type 2 diabetes treatments.
articles.title: A promising new pathway to treating type 2 diabetes

articles.description: Researchers have reported significant findings supporting the nutritional benefits of Connecticut-grown sugar kelp. They found brown sugar kelp (Saccharina latissima) inhibits hepatic inflammation and fibrosis in a mouse model of diet-induced non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, a fatty liver disease.
articles.title: Researchers find health benefits of Connecticut-grown sugar kelp

articles.description: It can be difficult to get young kids to eat enough vegetables, but a new study found that simply adding more veggies to their plates resulted in children consuming more vegetables at the meal.
articles.title: Serving larger portions of veggies may increase young kids' veggie consumption

articles.description: A new study found that plant-based protein shakes may be potential viable alternatives to milk-based whey protein shakes, particularly in people with need of careful monitoring of glucose levels.
articles.title: Potato and rice protein shakes may be a viable vegan alternative to whey protein shakes, research suggests

articles.description: A new study of postmenopausal women has found that eating a concentrated amount of chocolate during a narrow window of time in the morning may help the body burn fat and decrease blood sugar levels.
articles.title: Starting the day off with chocolate could have unexpected benefits

articles.description: Scientists have identified an internal communication network in mammals that may regulate tissue repair and inflammation, providing new insights on how diseases such as obesity and inflammatory skin disorders develop.
articles.title: 'Multi-kingdom dialogue' between internal, external microbiota

articles.description: Researchers were able to show for the first time that a very low calorie diet significantly alters the composition of the microbiota present in the human gut. The researchers report that dieting results in an increase of specific bacteria - notably Clostridioides difficile, which is associated with antibiotic-induced diarrhea and colitis.
articles.title: Dieting and its effect on the gut microbiome

articles.description: A typical Western high-fat diet can increase the risk of painful disorders common in people with conditions such as diabetes or obesity, according to a new study.
articles.title: Western high-fat diet can cause chronic pain, according to new study

articles.description: Eating fruits with lunch, vegetables at dinner and a dairy snack in the evening was associated with a reduced risk of early death by cardiovascular disease (CVD) and all-cause mortality, according to a study of U.S. adults. Eating a Western lunch (typically containing a high quantity of refined grains, cheese and cured meat) was associated with an elevated risk of CVD and all-cause mortalities in the same study.
articles.title: Starchy snacks may increase CVD risk; fruits and veggies at certain meals decreases risk

articles.description: Researchers have discovered a mechanism in a small area of the brain that regulates whole-body glucose balance without affecting body weight.
articles.title: Rap1 controls the body's sugar levels from the brain

articles.description: Diet rich in sugar and fat leads to disruption in the gut's microbial culture and contributes to inflammatory skin diseases such as psoriasis. Research shows that switching to a more balanced diet restores the gut's health and suppresses inflammation.
articles.title: Switching from Western diet to a balanced diet may reduce skin, joint inflammation

articles.description: Researchers have discovered a new mechanism controlling satiation. According to the recently published study, the hormone secretin induces satiation by activating brown adipose tissue.
articles.title: Secretin hormone induces satiation by activating brown fat

articles.description: Researchers have found that exposure to specific types of light before sleep can have variable effects on energy metabolism during sleep. Specifically, participants who went to sleep after exposure to organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), which emit polychromatic white light that contains less blue light than light-emitting diodes (LEDs), exhibited significantly decreased energy expenditure, core body temperature, and increased fat oxidation, indicating fewer negative health consequences compared with after nighttime exposure to LEDs.
articles.title: Exposure to light with less blue before sleep is better for energy metabolism

articles.description: A new study shows that a breathing exercise known as Inspiratory Muscle Strength Training can reduce blood pressure in weeks, with benefits on par with daily exercise or medication.
articles.title: 5-minute breathing workout lowers blood pressure as much as exercise, drugs

articles.description: A new study of postmenopausal women has found that eating a concentrated amount of chocolate during a narrow window of time in the morning may help the body burn fat and decrease blood sugar levels.
articles.title: Starting the day off with chocolate could have unexpected benefits

articles.description: Researchers have discovered a mechanism in a small area of the brain that regulates whole-body glucose balance without affecting body weight.
articles.title: Rap1 controls the body's sugar levels from the brain

articles.description: Researchers have discovered a new mechanism controlling satiation. According to the recently published study, the hormone secretin induces satiation by activating brown adipose tissue.
articles.title: Secretin hormone induces satiation by activating brown fat

articles.description: Listening to music while running might be the key to improving people's performance when they feel mentally fatigued a study suggests. The performance of runners who listened to a self-selected playlist after completing a demanding thinking task was at the same level as when they were not mentally fatigued, the research found. The study is the first to investigate the effect of listening to music playlists on endurance running capacity and performance when mentally fatigued.
articles.title: Running to music combats mental fatigue, study suggests

articles.description: In a new study, researchers show that a single dose of psilocybin given to mice prompted an immediate and long-lasting increase in connections between neurons. The findings are published July 5 in the journal Neuron.
articles.title: Psychedelic spurs growth of neural connections lost in depression

articles.description: Using datasets from neurosurgical patients and those with brain lesions, researchers mapped lesion locations associated with spiritual and religious belief to a specific human brain circuit.
articles.title: Brain circuit for spirituality?

articles.description: Azure API Management has now been updated to publish events to Event Grid.
articles.title: Public preview: API Management and Event Grid integration

articles.description: Azure API Management service has been updated to provide better support to customers through policy expressions and Power platform.
articles.title: General availability: Azure API Management updates - July 2021

articles.description: Azure Key Vault Managed HSM (hardware security module) is now generally available. Managed HSM offers a fully managed, highly available, single-tenant, high-throughput, standards-compliant cloud service to safeguard cryptographic keys for your cloud applications, using FIPS 140-2 Level 3 validated HSMs.
articles.title: Azure Key Vault Managed HSM is generally available

articles.description: App Service and Azure Functions have been updated to better support management of secrets as part ofyour secure application development process.
articles.title: General availability: Updates to secrets configuration options in App Service and Azure Functions
